author: @cmushel
text: I still remember the day when Scott Walker passed that act. My mom, who is a teacher, was absolutely devastated. Although both of my parents were very far left to begin with, that definitely got me more interested in more local politics and started me on my political journey. I think it really shows that until a political decision affects you or your family, it is very easy to become disconnected to everything that happens around you--a problem that I noticed a lot while going to a very conservative high school.

author: @SgtCandy
text:
A big underrated "eye opener" for me was 'Adam Ruins Everything'.  While he's not explicitly Marxist on set a lot of his stuff like why Cannabis was made illegal, how a monopoly will artificially inflate prices (his glasses and diamonds episodes) for profit, and the student loans crisis broke down the "capitalism just works" mindset I once had.

My college experience was push and pull, I was taking a class on labour and work in society while at the same time had a microecon prof say with a straight face to the class that to make two graph lines happy our pay needed to be low and our rent higher, she literally argued that.  That moment also sent me left in a hurry, but it wasn't until I really went "I need to actually read what the Communists wrote" that I found  what Marx, Lenin, and Connolly, etc brought to the table.

author: @fortedrummer3026
text:
Thank you, Eddie and Midwestern Marx, for sharing your story!  My son, who is a college student, introduced me to your YouTube channel. Bernie Sanders' campaigns were likewise my gateway to discovering socialism, and I naturally gravitate toward Marxism. I am a complete novice, though.

My path: I was a progressive Democrat for most of my life, always to the left of the party, and passionately anti-war. I never once supported the U.S. government's efforts to be in a constant state of war. Bernie inspired me to research and think in terms of democratic socialism. At some point during the COVID pandemic, my son encouraged me to listen to and read Marxist analyses of our current world situation. It all made perfect sense to me, and there is no going back.

I have always been a socialist at heart, but living in the U.S., I was trained or conditioned (programmed?) to reflexively reject and ignore socialist thoughts.

author: @ardianarki
text:
We as revolutionaries need to reach out to the working class and meet everyday people where they're at. So often we assume that everyone understands critical theory because for those of us who have been studying it for years it's become second nature. Critical theory does and should inform our politics, outreach, morality and pedagogy, but we forget that people are imperfect. Racism, sexism, hatred of the poor, heteronormativism and national and religious chauvinism are baked into our society. It is unrealistic to expect people to unlearn all these things they've been taught their whole lives on day one. As Malcolm X said, ‚ÄúDon't be in a hurry to condemn because he doesn't do what you do or think as you think or as fast. There was a time when you didn't know what you know today.‚Äù We need to have more patience with people while at the same time not tolerating bigotry of any kind. That means educating the people. I see people saying "it's not my job to educate you" but if you're a revolutionary it IS YOUR JOB!!! As the UK SDF wrote in 1883, "‚ÄúThe aims and objects of the Democratic Federation are before you. Success can only be achieved by organised effort:

Educate. We shall need all our intelligence.
Agitate. We shall need all our enthusiasm.
Organise. We shall need all our force.‚Äù

author: @redstarbetty7997
text: I was a fully convinced socialist as a teen back in the 80's - then the Soviet Union collapsed and I drifted away from it, gutted and disappointed. I began to believe all the people who said that it just doesn't work and capitalism is the best way, though imperfect, because it matches up with human nature etc etc. I believed that for decades, but more recently have really begun to notice and understand what forms western imperialism takes and how the intelligence services etc in a capitalist country can come to basically curate media information and control what people think. They're experts and I'm astounded at their skill in manufacturing consent (here in the UK, for example, people are so brainwashed by the mainstream media it's hard to describe how disturbing it is to hear them repeat all the propaganda in casual conversations at work etc!) I've gotten to see in my lifetime the words of Lenin proven true, especially what he had to say about imperialism being a sign of capitalism in decay. Once you see what Marx, Lenin etc were talking about in real time, you can't unsee it, and nothing will ever be the same for me politically now - I've come back full circle to socialism again.

author: @DD-wx4jc
text:
It didn't take me long to realize our wars were unwinnable and unnecessary after joining the military and leaving home to be my own person. First being assigned to the middle east, I realized we were an empire and became anti imperialist at heart, although I still worked for the military.

I was indoctrinated into a capitalist society like all Americans, but I never was pro capitalism. I grew up lower class and still am; I knew the economy wasn't fair. It wasn't until I was later assigned to spy on Chinese missiles that I wanted to understand marxism. I wanted to understand China and its people so I could be a better analyst, but also because I could see them building cities/infrastructure all over their country and that we had surrounded them with our military. They were in no way a threat to us; we intended to be threatening to them. I understood this when I was confronted by it in the real world. I had never truly considered the geopolitical implications of our military being stationed around the world and around China.

I was sympathetic towards the Chinese, which also spurred me to consume more domestic media and reports vs those from the US and its allies... and to read marx, and then Lenin, Mao... I was always a marxist at heart. Once I actually read theory, I became a marxist. I left the military and intelligence at the first available moment.

I love China. I believe they and the global south will save humanity from capitalism. They're going to turn the tide that forces change around the world.. and they'll do it peacefully, as siblings.

author: @RedPanda450
text:
I rarely use identifying labels but I think they‚Äôre relevant in this case. I‚Äôm a Chinese American guy who is really into history. Was the type of kid who would read ahead in the history book when I was in school. So I‚Äôve always been sympathetic to socialism because I knew about The Century of Humiliation and about what Ho Chi Minh did and why he did it. Also learned about the Cuban Revolution, the lead up to the Iranian Revolution etc. Basically consumed so much history that I became a leftist lol.

As for my political journey, I started out as a liberal then became a centrist and now I sympathize with socialism because socialists seem to be the only ones who are truly anti-imperialist. Also liberals love to talk but don‚Äôt accomplish anything lol.

author: @JohnnyZay90
text:
What radicalized me was doing some work for my brother in law and sister on their rental property over the course of a summer and spending a long amount of time actually contemplating the economics of the landlord/tenant relationship. I was asking my BiL questions about the business end of it and at one point, he even said the words: "If you do it right, they pay the mortgage." 

At any family gathering there will inevitably be a discussion of real estate break out and i have to bite my tongue because I know it will just sound crazy to them without laying a ton of groundwork and at the end of the day, they are materially more successful than I am so what I would be saying would obviously just be my jealousy.

author: @AnkharaHallstrom2000
text: I became a socialist back in 2015, when I was 15, people when I tell them I'm a socialist assume I'm either a socdem or some form of utopian socialist, I don't look like their image of a Marxist-Leninist. I'm not angry, I don't raise my voice, I'm known as someone who always has a smile on her face. They're always a bit startled when I actually defend the USSR. And why shouldn't I? My great-grandparents on my mom's side are from there, what's now Ukraine, I learned growing up about how great Lenin and Stalin were. I thought I was just a liberal until early 2015 (when I was still 14) and I read some of Marx's writings. I didn't fully embrace socialism until later 2015, when I was in 10th grade, and I've been a communist ever since.

author: @michelbeauregard7326
text: A very good testimony. Indeed, there are many things wrong with capitalism: as there are many things wrong with Marxism.  That's a debate for another day. For now, you have the enthousiasm of somebody who could make things happen. The challenge is to find a concrete problem that needs to be addressed, develop a plan to solve it, and muster the resources, human and material, to overcome it. Changing society starts by changing one's own community. A thousand miles  journey starts with a first step. I am looking forward to your first steps.

author: @te8701
text: I came on looking for a decent explanation of why an American would want to be socialist. This was disappointing and so weak as to be pitiful. So, To sum this up you pretty much said‚Ä¶‚ÄùI went to college and learned from a bunch of Leftarians and was indoctrinated due to my weak or nonexistent set of principles or virtues.‚Äù This Marxist professor wasn‚Äôt bias? Then how did you know he was a Marxist? Him informing you or any of his students of his political leanings indicates his extreme bias. A professor has a duty to remain objective and none of the leftarian teachers and professors ever do. They always wear their opinion on there sleeve and actively push it in their classes. Meanwhile while disparaging other ideas or any critique of their own. You said Bernie‚Äôs ideas and policies were ‚Äúcommon sense‚Äù, but you didn‚Äôt name a single one. Gave zero facts, figures, or any arguments about any political concepts. Gave no evidence that those critical of Feminism and BLM are ‚Äúweird‚Äù or why you believe that‚Ä¶.yeah, you sound like a political science major. Maybe study history a bit more. Marx called for violent overthrow of institutions based on destroying private property. So revolution based on theft. Just the rambling of a boring person that wants to piss off conservative mommy and daddy.

author: @Puzzlesocks
text: Interesting video. It's always fascinating how socialists/marxists cling onto and repeat the failures of capitalism while completely ignoring the incredible benefits of it. Then at the same time pointing out the theoretical benefits of socialism/marxism while completely ignoring the reality of what these policies lead to literally every time they are tried. I'm not sure why this video got recommended to me, but it's done nothing but reinforce my belief that this is some sort of mind virus that afflicts people who haven't advanced beyond black and white thinking and have a severe lack of understanding of the human condition, of history, and the reality of economics in practice. The issue always comes when you try to take your big ideas down from the ivory tower and implement them in the real world with real people.

replies.text: The reason why most socialist countries fail is because the west always makes organizations that their sole reason is to interrupt the progress made by socialist countries, also don't forget the sanctions and embargo

replies.author: @Puzzlesocks
replies.text:
@Blorpius I'm sure that's the only reason they fail. We don't even have to look at countries, and instead can just look at socialist policies and see the results are far worse than the alternatives.

And again, you can get into the psychology of it. Socialism hinges on everyone being unselfish and kind to function without quickly devolving into tyranny. It's completely unrealistic to anyone who hasn't lived in an isolated box their whole life.
